      • Stream.of()
      • .toArray()

  • My Java Toolbox

My Java Toolbox

Iterable

iterator()

1Iterable itr = itb.iterator(); // (?) Check type declaration syntax
2if (itr.hasNext()) itr.next();

forEach()

1itb.forEach(i -> System.out.println(i));

Collection

add() & addAll()

1col.add(e);
2col.addAll(c);

remove() & removeAll() & removeIf()

1col.remove(o);
2col.removeAll(c);
3//remove all elements that satisfy the given predicate
4col.removeIf(num -> (num%3==0));

contains(o) & containsAll(c)

1col.contains(o);
2col.containsAll(c);

equals(o)

1col.equals(o);

isEmpty()

1if (col.isEmpty()) return "wow";

hashCode()

1System.out.println("The collection " + col " has the hashcode: " + col.hashCode());

retainAll()

1col1.retainAll(col2);
2//remove all elements from col1 that are not in col2
3//used often with ArrayList, HashSet, etc...

size()

1col1.size();

toArray()

1Object[] arr = col.toArray();

Collection.sort(List, Comparator)

Similar to Arrays.sort() but for sorting objects in linked lists, arraylists, queues, etc…

1Collections.sort(alphabetList); //default is ascending order
2Collections.sort(alphabetList, Collections.reverseOrder()); //descending order
3Collections.sort(alphabetList, (a,b)->Integer.compare(a[0],b[0]));
4Collections.sort(alphabetList, (a,b)->a[0]-b[0]);
5list.sort(Comparator.comparing(n -> n.length()));

stream() & parallelStream()

1int res = col
2            .stream()
3            .reduce(0, (acc, e) -> acc+e);
4//parallelStream() returns a possibly parallel Stream with this collection as its source.
5//it may return a sequential stream like .stream()

Stream

A sequence of elements supporting sequential and parallel aggregate operations (e.g. see below). Similar to collection, but they do not store their own data, immutable, and lazy.

1int sum = col.stream()
2            .filter(e -> e.getColor() == RED)
3            .mapToInt(e -> e.getWeight())
4            .sum();

Stream.of()

1Stream<Integer> stream = Stream.of(1,2,3,4,5);
2Stream<String> stream = Stream.of("one","two");
3Stream<Integer> stream = Stream.of(myArray);
4
5//alternatively, directly from list...
6list.stream();

.toArray()

1String[] myArray = stream.toArray(String[]::new); //::new is constructor reference

collect()

1List<String> myList = stream.collect(Collectors.toList());
2Set<String> mySet = stream.collect(Collectors.toSet());

map()

 1Stream<String> res = list.stream().map(w->w.toLowerCase());
 2Stream<String> res = list.stream().map(String::toLowerCase); //equivalent
 3
 4res = Stream.of(1,2,3,4,5).map(i -> i+1); //> 2 3 4 5 6
 5
 6//without map()
 7List<InternetAddress> listOfEmail = new ArrayList<>();
 8for (Person p: people) {
 9    listOfEmail.add(new InternetAddress(p.getEmailAddress()));
10}
11
12//with map()
13people.stream()
14    .map(Person::getEmailAddress)
15    .map(InternetAddress::new)
16    .collect(Collectors.toList());
17
18//let's see what map() can do...
19assertEquals(Optional.of(Optional.of("STRING")),
20                                            Optional
21                                            .of("string")
22                                            .map(s -> Optional.of("STRING")));
23//nested optional? that's cumbersome, let's use flatMap()

flatMap()

1//useful for flattening
2assertEquals(Optional.of("STRING"), Optional
3                                        .of("string")
4                                        .flatMap(s -> Optional.of("STRING")));

filter()

1//filter all strings whose first letter is "f" (i.e. all remaining start with "f")
2Stream<String> res = list.stream().filter(str->str.substring(0,1).equals("f"));
3Stream<Integer> res = list.stream().filter(e -> e<10); //only elements under 10 remain
4
5List<Character> lst = Arrays.asList('C','a','0', 'B');
6lst = lst.stream().filter(Character::isUpperCase).collect(Collectors.toList());
7lst.forEach(System.out::println);

reduce()

 1//similar to fold
 2int res = stream.reduce(0, (acc, e) -> acc+e);
 3String res = stream.reduce("", (acc, e) -> acc+"|"+e);
 4
 5//another ex: finding max
 6listOfPeople.stream()
 7    .map(Person::getAge)
 8    .reduce((max, age) -> age > max ? age : max)
 9
10//another ex: concating names
11listOfPeople.stream()
12    .map(Person::getName)
13    .reduce("Names: ", String::concat)

limit()

1res = stream.limit(3);
2//the first 3 elements

distinct()

1res = stream.distinct();
2//remove duplicated elements

sorted()

1res = stream.sorted();

allMatch() & anyMatch() & noneMatch()

1boolean isTrue = boolList.stream().anyMatch(e -> e.equals("CHINA")); //if any true -> true
2boolean isTrue = boolList.stream().allMatch(node -> node!=null); //if all true -> true
3boolean res = boolList.stream().noneMatch(e -> e.equals("USA")); //if none true -> true

findAny() & findFirst()

1Optional<Integer> res = list.stream().filter(num->num<4).findAny();
2return res.isPresent() ? res.get() : 0;
3
4Optional<Integer> res = list.stream().filter(num->num<4).findFirst();

Collectors.groupingBy()

 1Map<Integer, List<String>> groups = stream
 2                                        .collect(Collectors.groupingBy(w -> w.length()));
 3//> 4=[Some], 5=[Somee], 6=[Someee, Someee], ...
 4
 5Map<Integer, Set<String>> groups = stream
 6                                        .collect(Collectors.groupingBy(w -> w.length(), Collectors.toSet()));
 7//> 4=[Some], 5=[Somee], 6=[Someee], ...
 8
 9Map<Integer,Set<String>> map = Stream.of("Some", "Somee", "Someee", "Someee", "Someeeee").collect(Collectors.groupingBy(e -> e.length(), Collectors.toSet()));
10for (int i : map.keySet()) {
11    map.get(i).forEach(System.out::println);
12}

mapToInt() [returns IntStream]

1IntStream intStream = Stream.of(1,2,3,4)
2        .mapToInt(e->e);
3int[] intArr = Stream.of(1,2,3,4)
4        .mapToInt(e -> (int) e)
5        .toArray();

Stream to List vs. Array

1List<String> lst = Stream.of("123", "456")
2        .map(e -> e.toUpperCase())
3        .collect(Collectors.toList());
4String[] arr = Stream.of("123", "456")
5        .map(e -> e.toUpperCase())
6        .toArray(String[]::new);

List vs. Array to Stream

1lst.stream();
2Arrays.stream(arr);
3
4// ex
5lst.stream()
6        .forEach(System.out::println);
7Arrays.stream(arr)
8        .forEach(System.out::println);

Array

initialization

 1//empty array
 2int[] intArr = new int[10];
 3
 4//with values
 5int[] intArr = new int[] {1,2,3};
 6int[] intArr = {1,2,3};
 7
 8//with values pt.2 using IntStream
 9int[] intArr = IntStream.of(1,7,5,3).toArray();
10int[] intArr = IntStream.of(1,7,5,3).sorted().toArray(); //ascending by default
11
12//filled with one value
13int[] intArr = new int[10];
14Arrays.fill(intArr, 1); // import java.util.Arrays
15
16//filled with consecutive values
17int[] intArr = IntStream.range(1,11).toArray(); // import java.util.stream.IntStream

Arrays.asList() vs. ArrayList(Arrays.asList(array))

former puts a wrapper on vs. latter actually takes each element and inserts them into a new ArrayList

1String[] stringArray = new String[] { "A", "B", "C", "D" };
2List<String> stringList = Arrays.asList(stringArray); // works ONLY FOR OBJECTS (int[] will cause error)
3stringList.set(0, "E");
4stringList.add("F"); // ERROR THIS DOES NOT WORK - FIXED LENGTH
5
6String[] stringArray = new String[] { "A", "B", "C", "D" };
7ArrayList<String> stringList = new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList(stringArray));
8stringList.set(0, "E");
9stringList.add("F"); // :-)

Arrays.asList() applications

To initialize HashSets, ArrayList, and Queues with value

1List<String> strList = Arrays.asList("1", "3", "5"); //wrapper
2
3ArrayList<String> arrLst = new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList("1", "3", "5"));
4HashSet<String> hSet = new HashSet<>(Arrays.asList("1", "3", "5"));
5Queue<String> q = new ArrayDeque<>(Arrays.asList("1", "3", "5"));

common use of toArray()

1int[] intArr = intList.toArray(new int[intList.size()]);
2Person[] people = valid.toArray(new Person[valid.size()]);

int[] to ArrayList<Integer>

 1ArrayList<Integer> arrList = IntStream.of(array)
 2                                .boxed()
 3                                .collect(Collectors.toCollection(ArrayList::new));
 4HashSet<String> hashSet = lstOfString.stream()
 5                                .collect(Collectors.toCollection(HashSet::new));
 6//to demonstrate...
 7IntStream.of(new int[] {1,2,3,4,5})
 8    .boxed()
 9    .collect(Collectors.toCollection(HashSet::new))
10    .forEach(System.out::println);
11
12List<String> lstOfString = Arrays.asList("AHEHEF", "AHEHEF", "EFEF");
13
14HashSet<String> hashSet = lstOfString.stream().collect(Collectors.toCollection(HashSet::new));
15hashSet.forEach(System.out::println);
16
17ArrayList<String> arrList = lstOfString.stream().collect(Collectors.toCollection(ArrayList::new));
18arrList.forEach(System.out::println);

[Static method] Arrays.sort()

1Arrays.sort(temp);

[Static method] Arrays.copyOfRange()

1int[] temp = Arrays.copyOfRange(array, start, end);

String

char[] to String

1char[] hello = {'c', 'o', 'd'}; // char[] is essentially String, so...
2String helloo = new String(hello);

charAt()

1string.charAt(0);

concat()

1strOne.concat(strTwo); // strOne+strTwo
2String abc = "abc";
3String cde = "cde";
4System.out.println(abc.concat(cde)); //abccde
5System.out.println(abc);             //abc

StringBuilder

1// if regular Strings were used => O(xn^2) time
2public static String joinWords(String[] words) {
3    StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder(); //resizable String / CharArray
4    for (String w: words) {
5        builder.append(w);
6    }
7    return builder.toString();
8}

length()

1String cde = "cde";
2cde.length(); // for ARRAY -> .length and for COLLECTIONS -> .size()

replace() && replaceAll() && replaceFirst()

1String cde = "cdefghijklmnop";
2//both replace all occurences of the pattern but replaceAll uses regular expression
3cde.replace("cd", "  ");
4cde.replaceAll("[^a-f]", "");
5//replaces only first occurance - uses regex
6cde.replaceFirst("[^a-f]", "");

split()

 1String str = "cdKef gh_ijKkl mnK*op";
 2
 3String[] strArr = str.split(" ");
 4Arrays.stream(strArr).forEach(System.out::println);
 5
 6String[] strArr2 = str.split("[K*-_]");
 7Arrays.stream(strArr2).forEach(System.out::println);
 8
 9//cdKef
10//gh_ijKkl
11//mnK*op
12
13//cd
14//ef gh
15//ij
16//kl mn
17//    <- empty String
18//op

startsWith()

1String str = "cdKef gh_ijKkl mnK*op";
2
3str.startsWith("cdK"); //true

substring()

1String str = "abcdefghijk";
2str.substring(3,6); // incl, excl -> "def"

toCharArray()

1String str = "abcdefghijk";
2str.toCharArray();

toLowerCase() && toUpperCase()

1String str = "abcdefghijk";
2String lower = str.toLowerCase();
3String upper = lower.toUpperCase();

trim()

1String str = " abcdefghijk   ";
2String trim = str.trim(); // "abcdefghijk"

[Static method] valueOf()

1String.valueOf(1); // "1"
2String.valueOf(false); // "false"
3String.valueOf('a'); // "a"
4String.valueOf(3L); // "3"

repeat()

1// Equivalent to Python's 3*"a" = "aaa"
2String str = "asdsa";
3String longerStr = str.repeat(5);

Integer

Integer to int (vice versa)

1Integer b = Integer.valueOf(5); // int to Integer
2b.intValue(); // Integer to int
3
4// auto boxing and auto unboxing works most of the time
5int a = integer;
6Integer c = a;

Integer to Binary (vice versa)

1// int to binString
2Integer.toBinaryString(someInt); // no padding in the binary representation
3
4// binString to int
5int foo = Integer.parseInt("1001", 2);

ArrayList

Resizable arrays, unlike arrays which are of fixed length.

Still O(1) access, amortized insertion O(1) (think of time it takes to add n elements - doubling operations contribute n/2, n/4, …, 1 which sum to O(n) which averages to O(1) per single insertion operation). Deletion is O(1).

add() && remove() && get()

1ArrayList<Integer> arrList = new ArrayList<Integer>(Arrays.asList(1,2,3,4));
2arrList.add(8);
3arrList.remove(0); // idx
4arrList.add(99);
5arrList.get(0);

set()

1ArrayList<Integer> arrList = new ArrayList<Integer>(Arrays.asList(1,2,3,4));
2arrList.set(0, 100) // param: idx, new_element

removeIf()

1ArrayList<Integer> arrList = new ArrayList<Integer>(Arrays.asList(1,2,3,4));
2arrList.add(8);
3arrList.set(0, 100) // param: idx, new_element

EDIT THIS

Math

Math.abs()

1int res = Math.abs(a - b); //param: int, long, float, double

Math.max()

1int res = Math.max(a, b); //param: int, long, float, double

Math.min()

1int res = Math.min(a, b); //param: int, long, float, double

Math.floorDiv()

1int res = Math.floorDiv(4, 3); //param: int, long ; 1

Math.round()

1int res = Math.round(7.43f); //param: float, double
2// Returns the closest int to the argument, with ties rounding to positive infinity

Math.signum()

1int res = Math.signum(7.43f); //param: float, double -> 1
2int res = Math.signum(-1); // -> -1
3// Returns the signum function of the argument; zero if the argument is zero, 1.0 if
4// the argument is greater than zero, -1.0 if the argument is less than zero.

Math.ceil() && Math.floor()

1int res = Math.ceil(x); //param: double
2int res = Math.floor(x); //param: double

Math.pow() && Math.sqrt()

1int res = Math.pow(5,2); //25
2int a = Math.sqrt(res); //5

double & float both represent floating point numbers, but double is more precise

Stack

import Stack

1import java.util.Stack;

push() && pop() && peek()

1Stack<Integer> stk = new Stack<>();
2stk.push(10);
3int a = stk.peek();
4int b = stk.pop();
5assert(a == b);
6assert(stk.isEmpty());

Queue

import Queue

1import java.util.LinkedList;

add() & remove() & peek()

1Queue<Integer> q = new LinkedList<>();
2q.add(10); // enqueue; add to the END of the list
3q.add(11);
4int a = stk.peek(); // return the FRONT/TOP of the list - i.e. 10
5int b = stk.remove(); // dequeue ; remove th FRONT of the list - i.e. 10
6assert(a == b);
7assert(!stk.isEmpty());

https://leetcode.com/problems/reverse-linked-list/

Conversions

T[] to List<T>

1Integer[] intArr = {1,2,3}; // needs to be boxed
2List<Integer> intList = Arrays.asList(intArr); // cannot add elements
3HashList<Integer> intList2 = new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList(intArr)); // fully functioning arraylist
4Stream.of(strArray)
5    .collect(Collectors.toList());

RETURN

IntStream

Creating IntStream: IntStream.of(…)

1IntStream intStream = IntStream.of(1,2,3,4,5,6);
2IntStream intStreamSingleton = IntStream.of(1);
3
4intStream.forEach(System.out::println);
5intStreamSingleton.forEach(System.out::println);

Creating IntStream: IntStream.range(…)

1// IntStream.range(lo, hi);
2IntStream intStreamRange = IntStream.range(0,11);
3
4intStreamRange.forEach(System.out::println);

Creating IntStream: IntStream.iterate(int seed, IntUnaryOperator f)

1IntStream intStreamIterate = IntStream.iterate(10, e -> e+2).limit(10);
2intStreamIterate.forEach(System.out::println); // 10, 12, 14, ... , 28
3
4IntStream intStreamIterate2 = IntStream.iterate(1, e < 100, e -> e*2);
5// identical to for (int i = 1; i < 100; i*=2*) {...}

toArray() -> returns int[]

1//toArray() -> int[]
2IntStream intStream = IntStream.range(1, 11);
3int[] intArr = intStream.toArray();

boxed().collect(Collectors.toList()) -> returns List<Integer>

1List<Integer> intList = intStream.boxed().collect(Collectors.toList());

Sorting Operations

Sorting Arrays: Arrays.sort(arr)

1// ASCENDING
2Arrays.sort(arr);
3
4// DESCENDING
5int[] descendingArr = IntStream.of(arr)
6            .map(i -> -i)
7            .sorted()
8            .map(i -> -i)
9            .toArray();

Sorting part of Arrays: Arrays.sort()

1// ASCENDING
2int[] arr2 = {100,21,3,4,5,6,62,1,2,12121};
3Arrays.sort(arr2, 0, 5); // inclusive lower bound, exclusive upper bound
4for (int i : arr2) System.out.println(i);

https://www.baeldung.com/java-sorting
